Its a hell of a good game. 10 of 10 BUT need some little tweaks.

Please make it possible to skip cutscenes when you die and fight Bosses again without to pause game and have that delay to skip.

Make it possible to SAVE EVEYWHERE instead to be forced to a flag and rest. If you die and not found a flag in 2 hours well just start over again. So annoying to need to camp and rest at flag and go back again just to continue.

And also in act 3, some guidelines how to proceed because the gap in Act 3 form 2 is damn big. Not a clue what to do, all enemy are OP as fuck and specially with the dumb saving system.

Otherwise the game is a damn good game! üòÖ

snippet.textDisplay:
Why everything has to be dark souls ffs.

Granted, the game isnt the worst offender since it autosaves everywhere, but the DS infused a GODDAMN TURN BASED game make combats a chore, even the most random ennemies.

They make dodge/parries mandatory with qte mechanics where the two options are 1)life saved 2)your whole health bar gone or drained to 10%.

Give me attacks that cut 30% of my health if i fail and only 15% or something if i succeed. The basics of turn base rpgs are about expecting to get hit and using your skills strategically to mitigate it and make it through the fights, not being punished over a game of "mash the button at right time or die"

Especially when foes throw long ass attacks just so you screw the dodge/parry over because of the drawn out expectation.

snippet.textDisplay: I have always absolutely hated turn based combat games with a passion. However, this game has completely changed my mind and flipped the script. I love the combat gameplay, the story, the soundtrack. I bought it because I thought it looked ‚Äúokay‚Äù and I would ‚Äúgive it a go‚Äù. However I‚Äôm completely hooked on it and absolutely love it. Cannot put it down. I hope the developer genuinely wins some game awards for what they have made. This is my favourite game of 2025 so far. Absolutely fantastic experience.
snippet.textOriginal: I have always absolutely hated turn based combat games with a passion. However, this game has completely changed my mind and flipped the script. snippet.textDisplay: Where to start... At first, I was never a big fan of turn-based games, but when I saw the magnificent trailer, I said, "Why not play it?" Once I saw the introduction to the game, I was impressed. Thereafter, the game took things to a whole new level: combat mechanics (impeccable and attractive), the soundtrack (I don't want to exaggerate, but for me, it's the best music I've ever seen in a video game, and I've played a LOT), the spectacular graphics, the simply mind boggling characters (how realistic they looked in the scenes was just amazing) the cinematography was one of the best aspects of the game, sublime, beautiful, and motivating. I just couldn't skip a second of that cinematographic artwork from start to finish. It is a game that, if you play it in default (expeditionary) mode, obviously it is not easy or difficult, but you will need excellent reflections and a good memory to remember enemy attacks. Each character is exquisite, the English voice performance is perfect, and my favorite character was Maelle (simply beautiful). The game took me 25 hours to complete just the story mode in expeditionary difficulty, and let me say, the difficulty was more difficult than I thought (especially with bosses like the two Axons, Paintress, Renoir (the third and last time) and some mini bosses), but it was worth it. The game is quite long; Play slowly, don't skip the cinematics (I recommend it), and you will fall in love with this work of art. Without a doubt, for me, this is the best video game I have ever played, and there is still much more to go through. Everything absolutely: 10/10 .. Highly recommended.

snippet.textDisplay: A game filled with philosophy and aesthetics is a good game, especially when it has a story that offers profound insights into life. The characters in this game are vividly contrasted, representing realism and existentialism. The developers used paintings as the conceptual backdrop, further emphasizing the underlying meaning. "Death Stranding" is another example of a game that merges cinematic storytelling with gameplay, enhanced by appropriate music, creating a deeply immersive experience that captivates players. Its poignant beauty lingers long after.

snippet.textDisplay: Quick word.:) .Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 demonstrates how making games affordable can lead to premium value, exceptional graphics, and top-tier mechanics, all while focusing on a rich single-player experience. I‚Äôm genuinely surprised and gradually more impressed by this dark fantasy game and its stunning 3D world. The gameplay, story, characters, and mechanics are all delivering at a high level. I truly appreciate Sandfall Interactive's dedication to creating such a remarkable title within an affordable framework, especially since I'm not typically a fan of turn-based RPGs. This 3D title is a very pleasant and matching example of how a refreshed and remodeled generation game has the potential to open some minds and perhaps inspire others to follow in their footsteps in the future!

snippet.textDisplay:
This game is a prime example of avoiding trying anything original, but instead focuses on doing everything right. In fact, they did it so right that you won't even care that the game is derivative of other turn-based RPGs. You'll be too immersed in the characters, the story, the themes, the visuals, the music, and the concept as a whole to care! They understood exactly that every piece I mentioned had to work together to make the game good. The characters had to be interesting and motivated. The visuals had to sell the world's immersion. The music needed be good, but actually memorable. The gameplay had to be strategic. Nothing was overlooked. Every piece was treated like it was important and given upmost care and consideration.

A game that truly did learn "from those who came before."

snippet.textDisplay:
*Review of Clair Obscur: Expedition 33*

In a gaming landscape saturated with formulaic mechanics and predictable narratives, Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 emerges as a tour de force and a breath of fresh air. This game is a resounding reminder of the emotional power and rich storytelling that can be found in the realm of interactive entertainment. From the moment you embark on this journey, you are reminded that games can evoke genuine feelings and resonate with real-life experiences in profound ways.

At its core, Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is a masterclass in the art of narrative design. The writers have crafted an emotionally charged story that doesn‚Äôt shy away from the complexities of human experience‚Äîloss, hope, resilience, and the delicate intertwining of light and darkness. Each character is richly developed, offering players an opportunity to connect with their struggles and triumphs. The game navigates themes that feel honest and relatable, making each decision weighty and impactful.

The homage to traditional Japanese role-playing games (JRPGs), particularly through its turn-based battle system, is both a nostalgic nod and a seamless integration. In a genre that shaped the gaming world, Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 manages to pay its respects while carving out its own identity. The battles are not mere exercises in strategy; they are extensions of the characters‚Äô journeys, filled with unique abilities and interactions that reflect their emotional growth.

snippet.textDisplay:
Basically, got fired from whatever companies like EA, Ubisoft, whatever. Replaced by rookies hired to freshen and diversify (basically to pay less, as always, by the greedy corpo) the teams working on games. Dudes were like "hey, we've got experience, there's enough of us and we know how to make them games like we used to - enjoyable and rich", so they just played off of their strengths and after assembling - made a game.
A good game. And probably great compared to those that are releasing by the big studios in this, nowadays, gaming famine.
